comments:
OS:	windows XP 
Language:	Traditional Chinese
Build level: 	3.1 M6
JDK version:  IBM JDK 1.4.2 SP1a
Test case #: TPTP05  

Summary: DBCS3.1: Log File remains even after Profiling Project is deleted

Steps to recreate problem:
1-Import a Log File, and Add Apache HTTP Server access log.
Under Details, browse to the location of the log file.
Under Destination, enter "project1" for Project and "monitor1" for Monitor.
Switch to the Profiling and Logging Perspective.

2-In the Navigator View, delete "project1" and its contents.

3-Look at the Log Navigator View.

 ....

Error:  The imported Log File still exists in the Log Navigator View.  If you 
open Properties, it shows that the Profiling Project, which was originally
"project1", is now "Profile Project", which actually doesn't exist.

In some cases this anomaly has lead to errors such as the "Import Log File" 
dialog not closing properly after a subsequent attempt of importing another log 
file.

But after seeing "Profile Project"--which was never even created--listed under 
Properties, a bug clearly exists here.  

Expected Result:   The corresponding Log File(s) should be deleted whenever a 
Profiling Project is deleted.

Created an attachment (id=20036)
log file used in the test case

A subproblem exists (mentioned above) where the Import Log File dialog does not 
close after pressing Finish.  To recreate this subproblem, do the following 
steps:

1)  Import Log File, Add Apache HTTP Server Access Log, and enter "project1" 
and "monitor1" as the Destination.

2)  In the Navigator view, delete "project1" (complete delete).

3)  In the Log Navigator view, delete the imported Log File.

4)  Re-do the Import Log File again, but this time use the previously saved 
configuration (i.e., do not add a new one).  

5)  Press Finish.  The Import Log File dialog does not close.
The build level is 200504151511.  (200504101503 also has the problem)

Alex, this seems to be a regression of bug 82637. Can you please take a look at it.
This can be reproduced on Win2k eng driver.

The subpart problem throws the following exception:
